metadata.description: Bemba as spoken in Northern Zambia and Copperbelt region

examples: Ulya mwana ponono - That rich kid
Bena mwana ponono - They are rich kids
mwana ponono.culturalContext: Modern slang term used to describe children from wealthy families, often implying privileged upbringing

examples: Katapa naipya - The cassava leaves are ready
Ndefwaya katapa - I want cassava leaves
katapa.culturalContext: Common vegetable dish in Bemba cuisine, often prepared with groundnut powder and other ingredients

examples: Kalembula iyi isuma - The sweet potato leaves are good
Nalitemwa kalembula - I like sweet potato leaves
kalembula.culturalContext: Nutritious leafy vegetable commonly used in traditional Zambian cuisine

examples: Bondwe nalipya - The amaranth is ready
Bondwe iyi isuma - The amaranth is good
bondwe.culturalContext: Traditional leafy vegetable rich in nutrients, commonly used in Zambian cooking

yama.culturalContext: Used to refer to one's uncle, showing respect

examples: Amaso yalemoneka - Puberty hair is visible
amaso.culturalContext: Used in discussions about puberty and physical development
amaso.usage: Used in health education and discussions about adolescence

ubwamba.culturalContext: Used in health education and anatomical discussions

umukate.culturalContext: Common food item in modern Bemba diet

examples: Umuntu aleisa - A person is coming
umuntu.culturalContext: Central to Bemba concept of humanity (ubuntu)

examples: Muli shani bonse? - How are you all?
Muli shani mukwai? - How are you sir/madam?

ukubomba.culturalContext: Work ethic is highly valued in Bemba culture

examples: Mfumu naisa - The chief has arrived
mfumu.culturalContext: Hereditary leader with significant cultural authority

icupo.culturalContext: Sacred institution involving families and community

umushi.culturalContext: Traditional settlement unit in Bemba society

examples: Twakumana ku nsaka - We meet at the insaka
Insaka ya mfumu - Chief's meeting place
insaka.culturalContext: Traditional meeting place for men to discuss community matters

examples: Ubwali bwapya - The porridge is ready
Ubwali ne sabi - Porridge and fish
Ukupita ichisungu - To go through initiation
ichisungu.culturalContext: Important rite of passage for young women

examples: Amafunde ya mbusa - Marriage instructor's teachings
Tabesha ukubomba - They don't try to work
Tabesha ukusambilila - They don't try to learn
tabesha.culturalContext: Used to express lack of effort or initiative

examples: Ni chovele wa basi - He is a bus driver
chovele.culturalContext: Common term for someone who drives vehicles professionally or personally

laka.culturalContext: Modern slang term used to express approval

jila.culturalContext: Slang term for any motorized vehicle

examples: Ndeya pa msiika - I'm going home
Ndi pa msiika - I'm at home
pa msiika.culturalContext: Slang term for one's residence or home

ukupopoka.culturalContext: Slang term for being well-dressed or attractive

examples: Alefwaya ukwicheme - They want to humble themselves
icheme.culturalContext: Slang term encouraging humility or modesty

umupondo.culturalContext: Slang term of respect for someone highly skilled or in charge

examples: Lazo aleisa - A thief is coming
lazo.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who steals

examples: Natamfya ichiwa - I gave money as a gift
Ukutamfya ichiwa kuli bane - To give money as a gift to friends
Ukufuta line tekuti - Bribing is not allowed
ukufuta line.culturalContext: Slang term for giving a bribe

examples: Ukuyubula ulucelo - Waking up in the morning
ukuyubula.culturalContext: Slang term for getting up or awakening

examples: Mulololo fye - Just take it easy
mulololo.culturalContext: Slang expression encouraging relaxation or calmness

ichilazi.culturalContext: Slang term for money or cash

examples: Pomboloka we - Get out of here
Alefwaya ukupomboloka - They want to get out of here
pomboloka.culturalContext: Slang term for leaving or getting away

examples: Mwiesha ukuba alizinkimana - Don't be very dull
alizinkimana.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who is slow to understand or boring

examples: Nashila ku ng'anda - I'm going home
nashila.culturalContext: Slang term for departing or leaving

examples: Colour yadeke sana - Very light complexion
colour yadeke.culturalContext: Slang term describing light skin tone

examples: Ni umuginbozi musuma - He's a good guy
umuginbozi.culturalContext: Slang term for a male person or friend

examples: Nzinga yaluba - The cell phone is lost
nzinga.culturalContext: Slang term for mobile phone or cellular device

examples: Lamya yaluba - The cell phone is lost
lamya.culturalContext: Slang term for mobile phone or cellular device

examples: Ndeya mu base - I'm going to town
Ndi mu base - I'm in town
mu base.culturalContext: Slang term for being in the urban area or city center

examples: Ndeya mu kalale - I'm going to town
Ndi mu kalale - I'm in town
mu kalale.culturalContext: Slang term for being in the urban area or city center

examples: Mwiesha ukuba mbuli - Don't be a pretender
mbuli.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who pretends or acts fake

examples: Mwiesha ukuba kembo - Don't be a pretender
kembo.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who pretends or acts fake

examples: Ndeya ku digo - I'm going home
digo.culturalContext: Slang term for one's residence or home

examples: Ndeya ku bondi - I'm going home
bondi.culturalContext: Slang term for one's residence or home

examples: Ndeya ku incry - I'm going to the funeral
incry.culturalContext: Slang term for a funeral or memorial service

examples: Ndeya ku sililoto - I'm going to the funeral
sililoto.culturalContext: Slang term for a funeral or memorial service

ukumoga.culturalContext: Slang term for death or dying

examples: Mwiesha ukuba beam - Don't be drunk
Muda aleisa - A witch is coming
muda.culturalContext: Slang term for someone believed to practice witchcraft

umupalyanda.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who is either physically tough or mentally sharp

akamutaka.culturalContext: Slang term for nshima, a traditional staple food made from maize meal

examples: Nakwatamo touch - I got my share
Ukukwatamo touch kwaliba - Getting a share has occurred
ukukwatamo touch.culturalContext: Slang term for receiving or getting one's portion or share

nachuma.culturalContext: Slang term expressing lack of money

examples: Mwiesha ukuba uwaoyo - Don't be fake
uwaoyo.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who is insincere or pretentious

examples: Kuli pampanga - There's an open pit
Pampanga yaliba - The pit is there
pampanga.culturalContext: Slang term for an open pit or hole

examples: Mwiesha ukuba bakamucheka - Don't be hypocrites
bakamucheka.culturalContext: Slang term for people who are two-faced or hypocritical

dibili.culturalContext: Slang term indicating a large quantity

ukupaking'a.culturalContext: Slang term for taking a break or resting

inkida.culturalContext: Slang term for nshima, a traditional staple food made from maize meal

examples: Mwiesha ukuba kemba - Don't be powerless
kemba.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who lacks influence or power

examples: Nakataka ya bantu yalongana ku market - A cloud of people gathered at the market
Nakataka ya bana balefwaya ukumona president - A crowd of children wanted to see the president
nakataka.culturalContext: Used to describe large gatherings or crowds of people, often in public spaces or events
nakataka.usage: Informal term used to describe crowds or large groups of people

ukutalala.culturalContext: Slang expression for feeling good or content

examples: Tulako amatwi ifyo cali - Tell me about how it was
Tulako amatwi ifintu - Tell me about things
tulako amatwi.culturalContext: Slang expression used to show interest in hearing more details

umukuliba.translation: big bottle of wine or spirits
examples: Leta umukuliba - Bring the big bottle
Umukuliba wapwa - The big bottle is finished
umukuliba.culturalContext: Slang term for large alcohol container

umutondo.translation: big bottle of wine or spirits
examples: Leta umutondo - Bring the big bottle
Umutondo wapwa - The big bottle is finished
umutondo.culturalContext: Slang term for large alcohol container

ukugeba.culturalContext: Modern slang term for being engaged in work or activity

examples: Zambia kuchalo, tuleya kuntanshi - Zambia to the world, we're going forward
zambia kuchalo.culturalContext: Popularized by Y Celeb, a Zambian musician, as a phrase expressing national pride and global ambition. Used to celebrate Zambian culture and achievements on the international stage

examples: Nakanana nomba - The situation is bad now
nakanana.culturalContext: Slang term describing a difficult or chaotic situation

paselo.culturalContext: Slang term for law enforcement or police officers

kanene.culturalContext: Slang term referring to someone under 16 years of age

umupondo.translation: a person who has struggled to succeed
examples: Ni umupondo - They've struggled to succeed
umupondo.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who has overcome difficulties to achieve success

sabala.translation: a person who has struggled to succeed
examples: Ni sabala - They've struggled to succeed
sabala.culturalContext: Slang term for someone who has overcome difficulties to achieve success

mokwana.culturalContext: Slang term indicating sufficiency or adequacy

chitika.culturalContext: Slang term for achieving success or accomplishing something

ukubeka.culturalContext: Slang term for achieving success or accomplishing something

examples: Ni ichibele - It's an evil altar
Ichibele chaliba - There's an evil altar
ichibele.culturalContext: Slang term referring to a place or object associated with evil practices

examples: Ukugoleka ichipaso - To sell a car
ukugoleka.culturalContext: Slang term for selling or trading items, particularly vehicles

ichipaso.translation: vehicle (particularly Toyota Hilux or Ford Ranger)
examples: Ichipaso chaliba - The vehicle is there
ichipaso.culturalContext: Slang term specifically referring to pickup trucks like Toyota Hilux or Ford Ranger

examples: Ninkwata inzinga - I have a cell phone
inzinga.culturalContext: Modern slang term for mobile phones, reflecting technology adoption in urban culture

lamya.culturalContext: Alternative slang term for mobile phones

bangala.culturalContext: Alternative slang term for mobile phones

examples: Kuba kwalula sana - Really beating them
kuba kwalula.culturalContext: Slang expression for dominating or outperforming others

bogade.culturalContext: Slang term for residence or home

examples: Ndeya ku kange - I'm going to school

ukusabuka.culturalContext: Slang term for being well-dressed or attractive

impolomina.culturalContext: Slang term for heavy-duty or combat-style boots

umu queen.culturalContext: Modern slang term showing respect for one's mother, combining Bemba with English

gaddafi.culturalContext: Slang term for father, possibly referencing authority or leadership

nachinya.culturalContext: Slang term describing something that is completely full or crowded

examples: Inkeche shileisa - The girls are coming
inkeche.culturalContext: Slang term for young women or girls

ukuzika.culturalContext: Slang term for giving or sharing something

chi takeaway.culturalContext: Derogatory slang term for sex workers

examples: Makangala nalipya - The kiwano fruit is ripe
Nalitemwa makangala - I like kiwano fruit
makangala.culturalContext: Kiwano, also known as the African horned cucumber or jelly melon, is a tropical fruit with a distinctive, spiky exterior. It has a bright orange rind when ripe and a lime-green, jelly-like flesh inside. The flavor is often described as a mix of cucumber, zucchini, and kiwi.

examples: Mankangala nalipya - The kiwano fruit is ripe
Nalitemwa mankangala - I like kiwano fruit
mankangala.culturalContext: Kiwano, also known as the African horned cucumber or jelly melon, is a tropical fruit with a distinctive, spiky exterior. It has a bright orange rind when ripe and a lime-green, jelly-like flesh inside. The flavor is often described as a mix of cucumber, zucchini, and kiwi.

examples: Ukwimba amalumbo - To sing praise songs
Amalumbo ya mfumu - Chief's praise songs
amalumbo.culturalContext: Traditional songs for ceremonies and celebrations

examples: Ukulwa no buloshi - To fight witchcraft
Ubuloshi tabusuma - Witchcraft is not good
ubuloshi.culturalContext: Negative spiritual practice in traditional belief

examples: Ulupanga lwatwa - The machete is sharp
Ukubomfya ulupanga - To use a machete
ulupanga.culturalContext: Essential tool for farming and clearing land

examples: Ukubomfya inkasu - To use a hoe

shikulu.culturalContext: Respected elder and source of wisdom

nakulu.culturalContext: Respected elder and keeper of traditions

examples: Kalulu wakosa - The hare is clever
Ilyashi lya kalulu - Story about the hare
kalulu.culturalContext: Common character in traditional stories, known for cleverness

umuti.culturalContext: Used for both modern and traditional medicine

ubulungu.culturalContext: Used in traditional ceremonies and as personal adornment

examples: Ikala pa chipuna - Sit on the stool
ichipuna.culturalContext: Traditional seating, special stools for leaders

examples: Ukuuma ingoma - To beat the drum
ingoma.culturalContext: Sacred instrument used in ceremonies and celebrations

examples: Ukulisha ulunkunku - To play the thumb piano
ulunkunku.culturalContext: Traditional musical instrument for entertainment and ceremonies

insoselo.culturalContext: Used for teaching wisdom and moral lessons

examples: Ukupela amatebeto - To give food offerings
Amatebeto ya buko - In-laws' food ceremony
Ichisekela ca mwaka - Annual harvest celebration
Ukuchita ichisekela - To hold harvest celebration
Ukuchinda umusambo - To perform traditional dance
Umusambo wa bemba - Bemba traditional dance
umusambo.culturalContext: Important part of ceremonies and celebrations

examples: Ifisashi ne sabi - Vegetables with fish

isabi.culturalContext: Common protein source in traditional diet

inama.culturalContext: Valued protein source and ceremonial food

icumba.culturalContext: Traditional cooking space, often separate building

examples: Ukupikila mu lupiya - To cook in a pot
Ukubika mu nongo - To put in clay pot
inongo.culturalContext: Traditional vessel for water and cooking

examples: Mu nshita ya lusuba - During summer
Umpepo yafika - Cold season has arrived
umpepo.culturalContext: Time for specific crops and activities

examples: Ilyeshi lyaisa - The flood has come
Mu nshita ya cipyu - During drought

ichilemba.culturalContext: Traditional farming plot worked with hoe

examples: Ulutanga lwakula - The pumpkin has grown
ulutanga.culturalContext: Important food crop with edible leaves

ulukasa.culturalContext: Important for traditional dances and movement

akanwa.culturalContext: Used in expressions about speech and eating

examples: Ndelya ubwali - I am eating porridge
ukulya.culturalContext: Eating together is important in Bemba culture

examples: Ndefwaya ukunwa - I want to drink
Inkalamo yakosa - The lion is strong
Ndeenda ku mushi - I am walking to the village
Imbwa ilelila - The dog is barking
Ukucema ing'ombe - To milk a cow

ukashika.culturalContext: Color associated with blood and life force

ukafita.culturalContext: Color associated with darkness and mystery

examples: Nalitemwa 5 years - I like giant kale
5 years ilipata - Giant kale is delicious
5 years.culturalContext: A popular leafy green vegetable in Zambian cuisine, known for its large leaves and nutritional value. The name '5 years' is believed to reference its hardy nature and long growing season.

examples: Ku kuboko kwa kulyo - To the right hand
Ku kuboko kwa kuso - To the left hand

pantanshi.culturalContext: Used for spatial and temporal direction

examples: Ukufwala ichitenge - To wear traditional fabric
ichitenge.culturalContext: Traditional clothing material with cultural significance

umunyina.culturalContext: Important family relationship in Bemba culture

mwana.culturalContext: Valued member of family and community

examples: Uli shani mulumendo? - How are you young man?
Mwashibukeni, uli shani mulumendo? - Good morning, how are you young man?
uli shani mulumendo.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young male, showing acknowledgment of their youth status
uli shani mulumendo.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young man or boy

examples: Uli shani mukashana? - How are you young girl?
Mwashibukeni, uli shani mukashana? - Good morning, how are you young girl?
uli shani mukashana.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young female, showing acknowledgment of their youth status
uli shani mukashana.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young girl or female child

examples: Ndi ne nsala - I am hungry
Insala yancusha - Hunger is bothering me
insala.usage: Everyday term for hunger or being hungry

Shongonono shalituntulu - The grasshoppers are nutritious
Mafulufute yaingila mu shuka - Thief ants entered the sugar
Nyenje shalila - The cicadas are singing
Ichipelebesha nacilapupuka - The butterfly is flying
ichipelebesha.culturalContext: Considered a symbol of beauty and transformation

examples: Impemfu shili mu ng'anda - There are cockroaches in the house
Ichipaso chilatoloka - The grasshopper is jumping
Mulengesha apupuka pa menshi - The dragonfly flies over water
Nakakonkote naikalapela - The praying mantis is praying
nakakonkote.culturalContext: Named for its posture resembling prayer

examples: Lunshi naikala pa fyakulya - The fly landed on the food
lunshi.culturalContext: Common pest associated with unsanitary conditions

Ndefwaya umwele - I need a knife
